description.text:
This is a simple print used to test non-thru holes in prints. This tests your printer's ability to print:

-Small hole depths (1mm and 0.5 mm)
-Small holes (1.55 mm holes and up)
-Small wall thicknesses (1mm & 2mm)

For dimensions of the part, see the attached drawing (in the images section).

The septagon (also known as a heptagon) in the corner is used to orient the print with the drawing.

description.text:
Heavy duty spur gear
Module = 3 mm
Number of teeth (z) = 16
Tooth design from http://hessmer.org/gears/InvoluteSpurGearBuilder.html
It endures big projects. Didn't make a keyhole because enough pressure on the screw will hold and delivers torque. Loose hole for M4 and tight hole for M5. It can be reopened with a drill to get bigger diameter (6 loop count on vertical shell).
If you scale you'll change the module. Cut it short in width if necessary.
22g of PLA
19g for ABS

dxf file with tooth shape is in the pack
step file to change hole (keyhole eg) is also in the pack

Foodsaver vacuum marinator accessory is a great way to quickly infuse steaks with marinade, but it has two problems. The first one is the meat floats. The second one is it doesn't. If it floats, the top surface raises above the marinade, if it sinks, the bottom of the steak sticks to the canister and does not get exposed to liquid. This grill solves both problems. Lay the small (bottom) part on the bottom of the canister, spikes up. Lay the larger (top) part on top of the steak, spikes down. Use the tall or the short ring, depending on the thickness of the steak, to push the grill down, the lid of the marinator must press on the ring and hold the grill and the meat down. The ring has a flat side and a chamfered side, the chamfered side fits into the groove on top of the grill so the whole thing does not slide sideways.

I printed this in clear PLA, PETG can also be used (do not use ABS).

title: Duplo to Wooden Train Track Adapter

description.text:
Inspired by my wife's desire for some fun additions to the play sets she brings to train shows and book signings, I decided to try my hand at creating a new version of this adapter designed to connect bricks compatible with LEGO Duplo up to your favorite brand of wooden railway.

It's heavily influenced by various other similar adapters that have been on Thingiverse for years, but designed from the ground up with precise measurements for the greatest brand compatibility, more kid-friendly rounded edges, and more internal structure to reduce the number of large bridges so you don't need to use support material when printing.

This was designed in Onshape, so you can access the design here, and edit per the CC license:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/6288ecdcde5b1428db4dd792/w/9fe8926a29b0ec517c74a316/e/d387b77bd8ffff99791c4e13

Printer:

Openbeam Kossel Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This was designed to print with no support, but a 2-3mm brim (both inside and outside) will really help with bed adhesion for the first few layers, which are very thin to stay within tolerances of the plastic brick of your choice.

description.text:
These are extensions for the Springfield Armory XDM series of pistols. These give
+2 for 9mm, I have not tested them with .40 but I believe that it should give +1. I do not believe that these will fit .45 magazines.

These use the factory magazine springs.
If your springs are old and worn out there may be issues with the slide locking back. Otherwise I have had no feeding issues or lock back while shooting. Pulling the slide back fairly gently I experienced some issues, however pulling with a bit more force it is reliable.
Update
I created a version that does not require screws to assemble, they are included with the others now.

http://amzn.to/2qd9GJY
These are the screws that I used, I had them laying around from another project.

This is a work in progress still, I am still testing and trying to get the look and feel to where I want it.

print_settings.Notes:: Snaps together and angle adjusts like the classic reclining pool chair back. The only post printing work I did was to file the corner round on the main hinge at the front so there is slightly more clearance for my case. Maybe someday I'll round the corner on the model, but its pretty quick and easy to do with a file or dremel. Works fine as is though. Gives a good range of adjustment from laid back to almost upright. The pictures are a little odd, but its tough to photograph the phone when its in the stand so I used a hard drive platter as a mirror. This thing works great in portrait or landscape mode. I might add some stick on rubber feet so it doesn't slide around so easily, but I'm pleased with the way it turned out. May it serve you well. Interesting note: The stander piece printed hollow in spite of having 50% infill selected, but it still turned out fine. I used 3 perimeters and 3 top and bottom layers. It took just over 2 hours to print all 3 parts on a Rostock Max v3 at 60mm/sec, Purple Inland PLA 218 nozzle-35 bed, fans at 50%

title: Spare pins for Legos, Mindstorms, and other building toys.

description.text:
It is so frustrating to run out of Lego Pins in the middle of a build. Now you can 3D print some spares.

Of course these are not as polished as the molded pins that come with your original product - yet you will find that these little 3D printed DIYer pins work quite well. So print a batch of 8 and resume building your masterpiece.

Long pins (23.84mm) and Normal pins (15.8mm) included in the attached STL files.

Printer:

Maker Select i3 and PowerSpec Ultra

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.2

Infill:

20% to 100% - may not matter for this print.

Notes:

Make sure you are printing with 3-4 shells. This design is so small and thin that I don't think infill is a factor.

These parts are pretty strong especially if you print them flat on the bed as I have originally oriented them. If you print them standing up they will be easy to sheer/break.

title: Dragon Curve Fractal Soap Dish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Dragon Curve fractal with a bowl like upper surface to hold hand soap allowing quick drying.
Or anything else you want to do with it.
Just Added: a version with a base, photos will be posted soon.
Note: The version with a base may need support to print.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm or less

Infill:

15% or more

Notes:

I printed in ABS, but whatever you choose be careful to check if it will withstand repeated water exposure over time. PLA should NOT last more than a few weeks in this application to my understanding, but I can easily be wrong.
Or if you want to use it some other way, well, then moot.

NOTE: If you print the version with the base, you might try with supports. I trimmed a little off the bottom and it SHOULD be safe to print without support, but no guarantee that it will be fine without.

More important for versio with base attached

If you print the version with the base you are going to want to sand this or use whatever finishing process works best for you and your chosen plastic. The layer boundaries are very visible.
Or you might like that look, it's neat if you ask me.
ABS acetone vapour smoothing should work great.
I printed in PETG, and as far as I know hand finishing with sandpaper is my only real option.
Don't use PLA, water breaks PLA down.

Designed with Inkscape (the curve can be procedurally created with the built in L-System tool) then used Blender to build an actual object.
Base was added in Blender.

Just because I think it's important, here is my own first print actually holding a bar of soap securely, easy to pick up, and lots of air circulation to dry the bar quickly. I would agree black actually wasn't the best colour, but it's the only colour I have ABS in.

comments.text: I like the one with the dish, but don't like that it's all one piece. Impossible to clean all those little tubes if they're closed on one end. Any chance you could separate the two objects?
comments.author: Kittish

comments.text:
I appreciate the frustration, but there are a few issues with splitting it into two:
-I messed up and accidentally overwrote the file that had everything separated. This means hours of work to split off exactly the right geometry, then all the fussing of filling holes, making sure the tolerances work etc. This is far and away the most important issue.
-I had a two part version I tried and it either slid around and never seemed to sit right or if I made a matching recess for it to sit in could just never get the tolerances right so either it would bind in place anyway or just end up getting a ton of gunk at the base and looking nasty.
Further the air pressure in a sealed at one end column tends to keep the soap out, so it's been rare for me to find any soap building up inside.
Now, normally I'd make the joke that it's soap so it's self cleaning, but I make my own soap and that can go rancid over long time periods, so I agree it's important to clean out. What's worked for me is just soaking it in water for a few hours, shaking it through the water occasionally and I've gotten the build up out that way. Added some vinegar which greatly eased the process but the water in this city is incredibly hard, so might not be necessary elsewhere.
I did try having the interface area right by the dish have an opening arch that passed right through the column so water could drain, but drops never really went down the entire column for me (droplet surface tension kept the droplets near the top) and it looked ugly so I scrapped that idea too.
So, sorry, it would be a huge amount of work which through experiment no utility was realized.
However, what I have done myself was put the one without a dish attached in a wide shallow soap dish I had, and that actually worked nicely. Not ideal but I like the effect I got.
comments.author: Kittish

comments.text: Fair enough. I actually think I found a decent solution. The dish part of the Coral soap dish remix (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:983849) fits the dragon curve rather well if you increase the width of the dragon curve by about 10 mm and the depth by about 5mm (I also increased the height by 2mm to bring the lowest point of the dragon curve just slightly above the lowest level of the dish) . At that size, it's not sliding around very much at all in the dish, and a tiny bit more fiddling with the size and it'll probably fit pretty close to perfectly.

author: krisirakasle

title: Impulse RC Helix ZX6 Fairing Adapter for KISS ESC's
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this fairing adapter for an ImpulseRC Helix 6" Frame to be able to use the KISS24A ESCs.

I upload two Versions of it. One is made to be printed in solid materials like ABS,PLA and so on. The other one is designed to be printed in flexible materials like TPU. Please don't forget to print the "standoffs" out of solid material if you want to use the the flex version.

I highly recommend you to print and use the flex version! There is still a chance that the solid one can break.

For the "solid" Version I am still looking for feedback because i added the pocket for the LED after my first build with the adapters, mine are glued in with double sided tape. So let me know if something doesn't work.

I used sandpaper to sand the LED's down to 9mm around one axis, otherwise they wont fit. I will attach a picture to show you where to sand(check if you have a short afterwards). I soldered two of the LED's in parallel to the corresponding pads. Both left arms togheter and both right arms. Make sure you use long enough wires especially for the back ones.

Please post pictures of you print in the Helix Thread on RCGroups or on Facebook. Would love to see all these prints!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S0e8uAh_uL0

You need to get a few new screws to assemble the Helix with the Adapters.

Front arms / M3x18mm Buttonhead:
https://hobbyking.com/de_de/metal-round-head-machine-hex-screw-m3x18-10pcs-set.html

Back arms with the Antenna Holders / M3x20mm Buttonhead: https://hobbyking.com/de_de/metal-round-head-machine-hex-screw-m3x20-10pcs-set.html

Motor screws M3x14mm Button Head or Socket Head :
https://hobbyking.com/de_de/7075-alu-m3-round-head-screw-14mm-gold.html
https://hobbyking.com/de_de/metal-socket-head-machine-hex-screw-m3x14-10pcs-set.html

LED's that you need to use:
http://bit.ly/2rHGdeB

30 AWG Silicone wire for LED connections:
https://hobbyking.com/de_de/30awgsiliconewire-black-1m.html

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PLA:
Nozzle: 0.40 mm
Extrusion width: 0.40 mm
Perimeter: 1
Top/Bottom Solid layers: 6
Speed: 60 mm/sec

TPU:
Nozzle: 0.25 mm
Extrusion width: 0.30 mm
Perimeter: 1
Top/Bottom Solid layers: 6
Speed: 25 mm/sec

Here is a basic puzzle of an angel fish. This design was inspired by similar puzzles that I had as a kid as well some pictures that I found while browsing the internet.  
This puzzle would be great for children and could possibly be used to help teach a unit on animals of the ocean

Print one of each of the STL files. Scale up or down to your liking.  
I also recommend printing this puzzle at 0.1 layer height to ensure that all of the pieces fit together properly.

author: sabharish

description.text:
Almost working methods for drawing in openscad.
Startup version of tube module.

This part directs air flow into the general direction of the extruder.  Most fan shrouds need to be attached onto the fan or bolted on the side, here the fan is mounted onto the extremity itself hence the name. The fan is meant to be parallel to the build platform, in my experience the fan is actually causing a problem with the quality of the prints. The wind tends to push the hot and very malleable plastic towards the back of the printer, here this allows the wind to be directed in a general direction while also performing its original purpose.

description.text:
Poppy Humanoid

Poppy Humanoid is an open-source and 3D printed humanoid robot. Optimized for research and education purposes, its modularity allows for a wide range of applications and experimentations.

You can buy all pieces by yourself (BOM link), or buy robot without printed parts on one of Poppy distributors.

About Poppy Project

Poppy is an interdisciplinary platform gathering beginners and experts, scientists, educators, developers and artists, that all share a vision: robots are powerful tools to learn and be creative.
The Poppy community develops robotic creations that are easy to build, customise, deploy, and share.

Useful Links:

  • GitHub repository (software and hardware)
  • Community forum to share things, ideas or ask help
  • Poppy project website
  • Education dedicated website (in french)

title: A 'Bright' Idea'...
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a fun mutli-purpose design that gets loads of attention!

The 'Bright Idea' is a large light bulb that serves as a container or a trophy to acknowledge great ideas and innovation. One of the fun aspects about this print is that, with heavy contents inside, like coins shaken to a level with the bulb angled sideways, it will sit on what appears to be an impossible angle... this creates an amazing visual effect!

The bulb part is printed separately and screws into the base. At standard scale the bulb part is 122m tall... so you need approx. 125mm Z / height capability to be able to print this (allowing for a Raft which helps ensure really good build plate adhesion as the print protrudes well beyond the build plate contact area).

This makes a great storage container for all sorts of small things. It's internal space is surprisingly large... perfect for money (coins and notes), small items of jewellery, electronics including cables and cards and much more. Very novel and a unique thing for yourself or to use as a fun gift...

There is one base file but two bulb files provided. One includes a coin slot that will allow coins up to 31.50mm to be inserted so should work for all coins in use in most major global currencies. The outlet hole in the base has the same maximum opening. If it goes in it can come out... you can also insert notes due to the height of the bulb.

Great ideas and innovation are highly regarded in this day and age so this design can also be used as the perfect award / trophy to present to people in recognition of their efforts in this area.

The base and bulb are intended to be printed separately and in different colors. To make the base multi-colored pause your machine after 5-6mm of the print has been built to make the base look more realistic (Refer to the images).

At standard scale the finished product is approx. 160mm tall with the two parts screwed together. This is a big bulb already... but uniformly scaling up should be okay. However, scaling down may mean the threads have insufficient clearance to screw together as is necessary.

This print requires a well set up, accurate and precise machine to ensure the threads print well and cleanly so will screw in/out freely. This will test how well your machine prints circles... because this design is "all" circles. Good prits look great and function equally as well.

Please refer to the images and print settings for additional information. And, if you print this design please post images of your 'Bright Ideas' for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 25% or more recommended

Notes:

Using a raft is strongly recommended to ensure the print stays well stuck to the build plate when the widest parts of the bulb are being printed. These areas protrude well beyond the base contact patch.

Do not use support as it may fill areas that need to be left empty to be a container. A well set up PLA machine with a filament fan should be able to print this easily.

This is a great test to see how well your machine prints circles... because it is "all" circles!

Almost nothing to do...

Remove the raft and clean up any visible filament excesses / debris particularly on the thread areas.

Next, its time to (gently) screw the bulb into the base... it's recommended to use a fraction of lubricant on the threads so they run freely, won't bind and become damaged. This shouldn't be an issue if you are careful the first time you thread the parts together. Thereafter it should screw together easily just like and nut and bolt.

This would greatly limit the coin sizes that it could be used with. The coin sizes this will accept in/out guided the design of this. Making a replica bulb is quite possible but making it functional as a coin box probably isn't going to work so well. Hopefully this explains the issue okay...

author: Lpasca

description.text: Griglia di protezione per ventola da 40 mm.
Autocad
this block makes adjusting the Z-level for the printbed endstop more accurate and stable

The stepfile includes the complete assembly for reference! -Remove Z-endstop
-put in 3 nylock M3 nuts in the block according to the drawing.
-put the switch in the block
-take out the left Z-rod
-drill a hole in the top, you should measure the exact location
-put in a M3 x 30 or longer with a washer, then add a washer + nylock nut from inside to fix the long screw in vertical direction. Tighten until it still turns but not moves up and down.
-screw the switch to the backplate with 2 M3 x 20+2 washers, until it is fixed, but still able to move up and down
-place left Z-rod back
-screw the long M3 in the block to finetune Z-height.
-optional: Once adjusted, tighten the screws on the backplate

comments.text: This worked brilliantly for me with a couple of tweaks. I added a heavy spring around the top bolt and i snapped off the little legs so it can be fitted without removing the z-rod. The screws from the back that secure the switch are more than enough to keep it from twisting.

author: Lpasca

description.text:
This is a saxon / dark ages mill designed for the 28mm wargames tabletop, but which can be used as a stand-alone/educational model. The building could also be used without the mill workings as a wharfside warehouse, and I have also included a blank rear wall so that the parts can be used to create a standard wooden hut (pictured)
It is based (with a large dose of poetic licence) on the archaeological finds as pictured on the Regia Anglorum site https://regia.org/research/village/acmylen.htm , which I then took liberties with.
For example I may have just invented the saxon sliding door!, but my rationale is that sliding doors are cheaper than hinges, and doable if there isn't a blacksmith handy.
The mill comes with a river section designed to be used in conjunction with my Modular Water sections ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2097314) but I have included a plain mill race if the mill is for stand-alone use. I also include small supports for under the piles so you can adjust the height of the mill if you are using your own river/stream sections.
Please note that the model comes with a grain hopper and support for controlling the flow of the grain into the mill grinding wheel, but they are not included in my photos as I thought they were a bit ott for a wargames model.
Oh - there's also a couple of flour bags to chuck round the model

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Painting

Undercoated in gesso,
Painted in acrylics
Varnished in matt soluble varnish, except for gloss used on the water

Support

The rectangular block is there to link, and provide support to the steps against the floor of the main building. If I'd been clever I would have made it part of the steps!

comments.text: Can you say me what scale is?
comments.author: slufan

comments.text: It's suitable for 28mm figures which is between/around/somewhere near 1:60,( but the subject of many internet debates). My pragmatic suggestion is to print out the porch door and then use your slicer 'scale' function to adjust it to your needs.

comments.text: Silly question if i may - the holder blocks - are these to standard spec - i have proper linear bearings - can i use these Holders?
comments.author: shearder

comments.text:
No, because I downloaded the drawing from the Internet, and they were all different ...
In general, in these details there is nothing complicated, I advise you to study any 3D program and make details of your size.
comments.author: shearder

comments.text: Why twisted ? What are the advantages ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: When twisted - gliding is better. I read it somewhere.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I doubt it ! Straight grooves in polymer linear bearings are to collect the dirt, grit. The way you do it, dirt, grit will be forced on the sliding surface. Never seen any polymer bushings with spiral groves. Now if you have references to the contrary, please post them. Note that on some "Babbitt", bronze... bearings there are spiral grooves but that is to distribute the lubricant.
Besides, in these 3D printers, the forces are not very important and there is no need for such big bearings. Smaller and half in length is enough. It reduces friction and weight.
comments.author: InfusionKRD

comments.text: Information received, thanx! Straight bearings are many, we will consider my LM8UU - experimental. And yes, in my twisted LM8UU - the grooves have not gone away. But, I will add a linear bearing.
comments.author: MKSA

author: Hinso

description.text:
This a box to protect & mount a mavlink-OSD / minimOSD unit to a model.
Mavlink OSD is an "on screen display" electronics module used to annotate flight & model status parameters over the live video feed.
There are numerous versions of firmware that can be used on the board.
ie : KVOSD, MWOSD
https://www.banggood.com/MinimOSD-MAVLink-OSD-APM-APM2-Flight-Control-Board-p-73436.html?rmmds=search
This unit is the same dimensions as my Ublox GPS case.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206426
You can use it with it's lid or stack it under the GPS case.
Screw holes in the case are 3.2mm designed for 3M metal screws and in line with the GPS case so you can run screws through both units to secure them in a stack.
There's additional holes for recessing screws as an additional mounting option.

PLEASE LET ME KNOW IF YOU FIND THIS USEFUL.
I'm also interested in what firmware is most popular for OSD.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

15% is good

Notes:

printing the base requires supports for recess under base to hide screws..
The lid doesn't require supports.
I printed in ABS but should be fine with PLA.

title: Low poly ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A low poly ring created with VECTARY https://www.vectary.com/l/Lowpoly_ring

How I Designed This:

  1. Create a torus.
  2. Select all points and bevel them to maximum.
  3. Select random faces and scale them up.
  4. Select all edges and bevel them a bit.
  5. Smooth object and then choose the color and material you want to be applied.
  6. Export the .stl file.

title: Festool parallel guide (3cm t-track) Updated! and Better a lot

description.text:
This is a parallel guide for festool, makita and triton copy track saw.
The way it works similar to festool parallel guide (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z7D0yrZY8vU)

This is my third design, and i'm pleased with it and no longer a remix, it is my original design.

This is only the hardware like https://www.senecawoodworking.com/products/parallel-guide-system-for-makita-guide-rail, you still need another hardware to make it work.

for one complete parallel guide (you need a pair) the lists are :
1) T-track with the size shown in picture, i believe it is more accessible rather than incra t-track plus
2) 2 t-bolt m8 which meant to be used with the t-track
3) 1 m8 knob
4) 2 m6 bolt and nut
5) 1 m8 nut
6) 1 stick on tape measure

More picture, information and how to calibrate would come later when i have finished my video.

Hope it help you all. Happy woodwork.

other

author: sabharish

title: The FIBIAC - a simple electromechanical computer

description.text: This is a proof-of-concept for building a simple electromechanical computer. Using a series of punch-cards, it can compute the fibonacci sequence (or other simple algorithms). Additional registers could be added to support more complex operations. See it in action here: http://chrisfenton.com/the-fibiac/

• Print and assemble three 3-digit counter registers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16068), including magnets and reed switches. Arrange them artistically (I bolted them to a sheet of plywood).

  • Use a laser cutter to cut out 'card_frame_base.dxf' (units are in inches). Cut out 'card_frame.dxf' next. Use 1/4" acryllic or plywood. Use L-brackets from a hardware store to assemble the pieces into a box with card_frame on top (this is what the card reader will get mounted to).

  • Print 2 copies of the 'hol_plate_holder.stl' file - this is the base of the punch-card reader and will hold a copper-clad board. Bolt these to the middle of card_frame so that the copper plate is in the center of the sheet.

  • Take a bare copper-clad board (http://www.goldmine-elec-products.com/prodinfo.asp?number=G18389 or similar). Cut the board to be 3.4"x2.25" (I used a CNC mill for this step). Using a file, file away a line of copper 0.8" from one edge of the board. This should divide the plate into two copper pads, roughly .8"x2.25" and 2.6"x2.25".

  • Acquire 32 spring-loaded pogo pins (with rounded tip) like these: http://www.sparkfun.com/products/9173. Get a piece of proto-board with .1" spaced holes, and solder the pins in place in an 8x4 grid, with 0.4" spacing between pins. The pins should be mounted about halfway through the protoboard, and the entire grid needs to be aligned carefully so that some pins don't stick down further than others. The current version only actually uses 11 of these, in case you are feeling thrifty, but it leaves room for expansion. Use a utility knife to score the protoboard on the rows of holes just outside the pins, and snap off the excess protoboard.

  • Print 2 copies of the 'hol_pin_holder.stl' file. These will hold the board we built in step 5 in place. Place 4 skate bearings (http://store.makerbot.com/skate-bearing-pack-8.html) on the studs of the hol_pin_holder pieces (2 each).

  • Use a laser-cutter with 1/4" acryllic to print out two copies of pin_support_grid.dxf. These will 'sandwich' the protoboard with the pogo pin array and hold the pins straight. They should snap into the 'hol_pin_holder' pieces on either side. With the bearings in place, this should slide into the hol_plate_holder assembly fairly snugly, and be able to move in the vertical direction. The pogo pins should all compress a bit when the pin array assembly is as low as it can go, in order to ensure good contact. 8 of the pins on one side should hit the smaller section of the copper board, the other 24 should hit the big side. Insert a 3/8" threaded rod and fasten with bolts so that it extends between the two hol_pin_holder pieces and secures them together. It should stick out 2-3 inches on either side of the hol_pin_holder pieces (this is where the servo_cam will grab it).

  • Print off two copies of 'servo_cam.stl.' You will need to mount these onto two HS-311 type hobby servos (http://www3.towerhobbies.com/cgi-bin/WTI0001P?I=LXDEL5&P=8 or similar).

  • Print off two copies of 'servo_support.stl.' Mount the servos with cams to these, and slip the cams on to the threaded rods, such that the servos can raise and lower the pin array by rotating. Mount the servo_support blocks on either side of the plate_holder assembly with bolts. The cams should be able to rotate 90 degrees to raise and lower the pin array. When in the 'up' position, there should be plenty of clearance between the bottom of the pins and the copper plate. When in the 'down' position, the pogo pins should all be slightly depressed.

  • Print out the 'motor_mount' piece, and attach a NEMA17 stepper motor. This will eventually advance the instruction card chain forward.

  • Use a laser cutter to cut 2 copies of 'instr_card_box.dxf' out of 1/8" plywood or acryllic. Glue them together.

  • Print out 3 copies of axle_stopper.stl. These will hold axles to mount the 2 instr_card_box things we built in step 11.

  • Using a universal mounting hub (http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10006) and some 4-40 bolts, attach the instr_card_box to the stepper motor from step 10. Attach motor mount to the frame so that it sticks out a bit into the larger of the 2 rectangular cut-outs. If necessary, add a bit of glue between the hub and the instr_card_box so that there is no play and it rotates smoothly. The top of the box should be roughly co-planar with the top of the frame.

  • Attach 1 axle_stopper opposite the motor to support the other side of the instr_card_box. Glue a short length of 5/32" brass rod into the axle_stopper so that it protrudes an inch or so for support. The instr_card_box mechanism should now rotate smoothly.

  • Use the other 2 copies of axle_stopper on the opposite side of the frame (with the smaller cutout). Cut out a length of 5/32" brass rod to go between the two axle_stoppers, and mount the remaining instr_card_box on the rod. It should be able to rotate freely (and there should be 10" between far edges of the two instr_card_boxes, such that a chain of 5 2"x3.5" cards should hang across them).

  • Get 4 stepper motor drivers (http://store.makerbot.com/stepper-motor-driver-v3-3.html or similar), and attach them to be able to drive the four stepper motors (3 to control the counter registers, 1 to control the card-advance mechanism).

  • Solder two long wires to either side of our copper plate beneath the pin array. The wires can be routed out either side of the plate_holder thing. The wire connected to the larger copper section should be connected to your system ground - this is now the 'ground plate'. The other wire should be labeled 'zero_detect' and left hanging for now (this section of the copper plate is now the 'zero_detect plate'.

  • Now we're going to control the counter registers. Using wire-wrap wire and your circuit-building-technique-of-choice, connect pins above the ground plate to the 'enable' and 'direction' signals of each stepper driver for the counters (This uses 6 pins). Make sure those signals also have 5V pull-up resistors on them (1k ohm is usually fine) as well. [optional] Use one additional pin above the ground plate and connect it to a buzzer and/or small 6V lamp. This will be our 'alert' signal. Connect the other side of the buzzer/lamp to +5V. We can now control the enable and direction signals for our counters by means of selectively punching holes in instruction cards.

  • Each counter register should contain 3 reed switches that will complete a series circuit when the register reads '0-0-0.' For each of the counters, ground 1 side of the series-reed-switch circuit. Connect the other side to one of the pogo pins above the 'zero_detect plate.' We should now be able to selectively connect a zero-detect circuit from a subset of our counters to the zero_detect plate. The wire connected to that plate will be grounded whenever the selected register is reading 0-0-0. Hard-wire one of the remaining pogo pins above the zero-detect plate to ground, so that we have a means of forcing the zero_detect plate to ground (i.e. automatically advance to the next instruction). The zero_detect wire should have a pull-up resistor (1k ohm is fine) to +5V.

  • Get a microcontroller of your choice. Use it to drive the servo PWM signals. Use trial and error to figure out appropriate values for your servos (Remember - they will be rotating in opposite directions) to raise and lower the card reading pin-array. You can hardware the direction and enable signals of the stepper controller used to advance the card chain such that it always rotates forward, and is always enabled. Connect the 'step' signal of the card-advance motor controller to a digital output signal of the microcontroller.
    • Wire all three 'step' signals from the three counter registers to the same digital output on the microcontroller. Wire the zero_detect signal (with pull-up resistor) to a digital input pin on the microcontroller.

description.header: Program the microcontroller with the following algorithm:
description.text:
• Lower pin-array.
  • Wait 1 sec.
  • Read 'zero_detect' signal. If zero_detect==0, skip to step 6. Otherwise, go to step 4.
  • Send appropriate # of step pulses to rotate enabled counter registers 36 degrees.
  • Go to step 3.
  • Raise pin-array.
  • Wait 1 sec.
  • Send appropriate # of step pulses to card-advance motor to rotate the motor 90 degrees.

  • Go to step 1.

  • Print out two copies of card_tensioner.stl as well as two copies of big_roller.stl. Bolt the two tensioner pieces to the frame such that they project downward underneath the frame. Cut a 5/32" rod to fit between the two pieces and serve as an axle for the two large rollers. The rollers should push down on the chain of instruction cards to keep them under tension (their height can be adjusted by moving the rod up/down the tensioner pieces).

  • Acquire 12 or more 3.5"x2" instruction cards (US business-card sized) - you will need to design a different tensioner mechanism to use more than 12 cards. I used a nice, coated card-stock for mine (my wife's spare business cards). Print out the 'punch_Card_template.pdf' file, and use a 1/4" hole punch to punch out holes corresponding to the signal pins you chose to use in earlier steps. I overlayed the template on each card I was using, and used a sharpie to stencil the hole grid onto each card.

  • Program it! Write a program to control your wonderful machine. A program to compute the fibonacci sequence looks like the following:

  • Enable R0, R2. R0=Down, R2=Up. Stop when R0==0.
  • Enable R0,R1,R2. R0=Up, R1=Down, R2=Up. Stop when R1==0.
  • Enable Buzzer/lamp. Ground the zero_detect plate automatically to auto-advance.
  • Enable R1, R2. R1=Up, R2=Down. Stop when R2==0.
    • To get 12 cards, I just repeated this algorithm 3 times. Every time the machine beeps / lamp lights, the next number in the fibonacci sequence is located in R2. With more registers, you could do more complicated operations. Punch out the corresponding holes on your cards in sequence, and then carefully align the card edges and tape them together with the tape on the bottom side of the card chain.

  • Feed the instruction chain into the machine and then carefully tape the two loose ends together, getting them as flush as possible (to make a circular chain of instruction cards).

  • Position the card chain such that the first card in your program is underneath the pin array. Manually lower the pin array to check for alignment. Power up your machine and let it go!

  • Bask in the glory of your fantastic, punch-card-based calculating engine!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7ANDCvJ9K61

The AO-100 is a MendelMax variant printer that has been slimmed down for a smaller foot print that matches the print size of the Prusa Mendel. With an aluminum extrusion frame the AO-100 is an extremely sturdy printer capable of printing quality parts at high speeds. The design is made to be used with Igus pillow block bushings that allow for precise movement with a high performace bushing. The reliable MK1 PCB heat bed is used to heat the borosilicate glass print surface. Although other electronics can be used, the included electronics mount is for the tested and true RAMPS 1.4/Arduino RepRap electronics. All of the source files including CAD files, print files, BOM, and manual are available at download.lulzbot.com/AO-100. The AO-100 is also available, completely assembled and calibrated, at LulzBot.com. Licensing
-Parts and files: GPLv3
-Images: CC BY SA

The AO-100_print_parts.tar.gz files includes all of the needed print files. In AO-100_BOM.ods you can find the required part count including all of the needed hardware.
We have made an extensive manual for the AO-100 3D printer. Although this manual is specifically for the AO-100 it is also informative on general setup for a first time 3D printer user.

title: iPhone 5 Car Holder for 2008 VW GTI

description.text:
I designed a simple holder for the iPhone 5 to work with the dashboard vents of my 2008 Volkswagen GTI. I have been using the holder for a few months now and really like it.
Feel free to share and/or to modify the design and let me know what you think!

After two failed prototypes, I found the perfect mix between stability and simplicity and had fine-tuned the viewing angle of my design. It slides easily into the dashboard vents and a hook prevents it from falling out. I opted to add five pieces of 0.5mm thick fabric (shown in red in one of the above illustrations and included both as PDF and DXF drawings) to protect my precious phone from scratching.  
For printing on a Solidoodle, I broke the product into four parts and the files contain 3D data both of the Solidoodle-version, as well as of the complete object -? maybe you can find a better way to deconstruct and print it?

title: 3D printed smart planter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Filaments.directory has teamed up with renowned 3D designer Augustin Flowalistik to create a 3D printable planter that will change the way you think about the potential of 3D printing. This functional device is equipped with an IoT module that will monitor the humidity of your plant’s soil, while also sprucing up the look of your home.

Our DIY planter will measure humidity every 15 minutes, sending the data directly to the Adafruit cloud. Using an IFTTT, you can connect to the Adafruit API and constantly keep up-to-date with the latest value. The IoT module even allows you add actions to automate the reception of this data through SMS messaging, Twitter, and others.

The planter without electronics is available on this page.
The IOT version is available for free on www.filaments.directory when registered.

The print settings are available here : https://www.filaments.directory/en/filaments/faberdashery/pla/orange-fizz-0-84-kg-2-85-mm

description.text:
I got tired of water coming into my kayak from the scupper holes. They drained fine but when it was windy and there were waves water kept splashing in, so I designed this simple scupper plug that has a floating ball check valve. If water gets in from the paddle or over the side it easily flows out but no more splashing in through the scupper holes. Give it a try and give me some feedback. It can always be made better so suggestions are welcome.

You may want to print the plug itself with ninja flex to allow it to seat in the hole better or you can simply epoxy them in.

Note: For assembly, epoxy the the grate to the scupper plug after putting the ball in side and it works pretty well.

remixed_from.author: abacker
remixed_from.title: 18650 snap-together tower of power (2,4,5,6 cell options)

title: Remix of 18650 x 4 top snap battery case screw tighteners for 12ga wire v7

description.text:
Update: 7/21/17
Finally gave up on this system. Did not realize that PLA has too much flex. Should have printed in ABS or PETG. System failed and on inspection batteries had all come loose to the point I could remove them by hand. I had tightened them once before.

I am moving on to a professional battery. Printing with ABS would help. This system should work fine for low current applications. All the batteries were fine and held a good charge even when the controller would shut off under load. The batteries read 4V but could not supply enough current for hill climbing (20a). Previously it did.

Update: 7/11/17
Learned a few things:

  1. The Waygo connectors are great but have a habit of coming apart when one of the rat's nest of wires catches them as you are riding around. I'm hoping electrical tape will fix that, or maybe learn to control the wires.
  2. The pack reliably delivers 25A in short bursts and 20A continuously. This has more to do with my battery selection but just to prove that it does consistently work.
  3. Anytime the system failed, it was because a battery fell out or wire came undone. The tops to the cases and now electrical tape fixed that.
  4. I have used it on a CNEBikes 48v hub motor x2 and their controller with no problems.
  5. More powerful controllers such as my Grin 35A must have the current limited by a Cycle Analyst to 20 to reliably work.
  6. CNEBikes sells a 48v 14Ah with rear rack for $450. My cost on this project had to be at least $400. I have the 36V 14Ah version with another motor and can confirm it works fine.
  7. The CNEBikes kit (sold by YescomUSA) come with a flimsy bag that has holes in it for cabling. I learned that if I used zip ties from the hose clamp on the battery, through the hole for cables and out to the rack on the bike, that the battery was far more stable. I also used zip ties to connect the bag to the rack and made it far more stable.
  8. As stated below, only do this project to learn or because you came into a bunch of cheap/free batteries.

    58.8V 13.2 Ah 18650 Battery Tower of Power
    14s4p configuration

Yes, it works.

Remix of 18650 x 4 snap together tower of power. I put holes in the back of the battery box so I could pop the batteries out more easily if needed. I made the holes large enough that 12 gauge silicone wire would pass through easily and adjusted the holes for the set screws on the negative terminal. I also stripped the wire completely rather than half of of. To insulate the wire I put plastic discs between the wire and the set screw. Not shown in picture, but I printed a top for the tower of power because on one ride a top battery fell out. I also had to tighten several set screws. Still looking for a nice case. to further insulate the batteries. I designed a 3D printed one but it was not practical for my printer. I am using 2 hose clamps to hold it together. The red stuff on the back is liquid electrical tape as I snipped off the wires left hanging out and covered them up. I used Waygo connectors to join the batteries in series. Very helpful when you you don't have a final design yet and have to make changes like adding sensor wires for the BMS. They held up fine. I had to use 6mm long screws to connect the boxes otherwise they would hit the battery. Last two pictures are the battery with controller in a bag mounted on the back of the bicycle. It is free floating but cannot move much because of the controller and associated cabling.

Finally, I would not do this again unless I was only making a 1s4p iPhone charger or similar. If you have access to someone's else's batteries then this might make sense. If you are buying new batteries (like I did, long story) skip it and buy a premade battery designed for your intended usage.

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6ejDhuVBx9D
Link to Top
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gKulN0wkpWc
Link to Disc
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bP2fL0EYBdA

Makergear M2

No

No

.5 nozzle with .4 layers
Used whatever PLA happened to be sitting around.

Originally I was going to make it 14s8p but the size is prohibitive in its current form. They have a max of 10A but it must for a split second because I only get 40A on a fully pack for maybe 10 seconds at a time.
I have a stack of the same charge boards you mentioned waiting to make simple iPhone charging module or a solar power recharging station this summer. Regarding capacity I use my RC hobby charger and pay attention to the amps when fully charged. That said, it times out at 5000mA such that I had to fully charge them more than twice so I don't really know the capacity except that it is over 10,000.

1. Create a box with 2 segments and scale down the ends.
  2. Bevel the edges.
  3. Use the Array plugin - radial and play with the angle and the number of

  7. Bake mirroring, smooth object and choose the color and material you want to be applied.
  8. Export the .stl file.

author: thomasasers

title: Bed Center Calibration Tutorial (using parametric crosshairs with square)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NEW! Parametric design added! The tutorial is updated with a new parametric OpenSCAD model which can be used (e.g. using the Customizer app) to fit your own heat bed/build plate. The parameters of the model are self explanatory; please note that the tolerance is merely used for ecstatic purposes (rendering glitches), so please do not change that one. The old STL files have been removed and some examples introduced as the old ones did not slice perfectly in Cura (they did go well in Slic3r though...). Please make your own center calibration STL by tuning it exactly to your printer setup.

What! Not in the center?
I noticed that with large prints part of my skirt or brims sometimes was printed outside the heat bed print area. Apparently, the printer does not have the correct heat bed center in the firmware.

This thing helps you to find the center of the bed and aids in changing the bed center to the actual bed center. Instructions are provided below for you to change your center.

Supported firmware
Note that this works for e.g. Marlin based firmware, e.g. Skynet3D! More firmware types are supported, see this page.

Note for unsupported firmware
For stock Anet boards (or if you cannot or do not want to mess with gcode) you can make this also work by printing spacers or custom end stop mounts.

Printer center seems to have an off-set?

With the stock firmware (a customized older version of Repetier) I have not tried to find a solution for my problem, but recently I updated my printer with an auto bed leveling sensor which requires an update of the printer firmware (to Marlin firmware). I updated to the latest Skynet firmware (v2.3.2 fix 2). Again I noticed that the prints are printed off-set of the heated bed center. This can easily be checked by printing the thing I uploaded here. The cross should be exactly in the center of the heated bed; the distance from the outer squares to the edge of the heated bed should be similar/equidistant.

Fix the off-set!

In my case the bed is off center by 2 mm in both X and Y direction (ignoring the signs here). There are a few solutions to solve this (see Marlin bed dimensions at reprap.org). As I closed up my main board after the firmware flashing (using a private remix (now publicly available here: 0scar's modular Anet A8 electronics casing) from c_wolsey's Anet A8 Electronics Case; I increased the height of the casing so it can hold a Raspberry Pi, the main board, a 4-channel relay module, an opto-coupler for the auto level sensor and a heatbed Mosfet), I had no quick access (maybe combined with a little laziness and lack of time) to change the firmware configuration file and upload a new version, so I decided to go for the second method: changing the off-set through g-code command and store the new off-set to the printer memory. In my case the center of the bed required an offset of -2 mm for the X direction (just measure in the X direction the distance from the outer squares to the edge of the heated bed and subtract the 2 values and divide them by 2; in my case this led to (8-12)/2 = -2 mm). A similar action needs to be done for the Y-direction; this resulted in 2 mm off-set.

Use a terminal to access the printer to directly send command to the printer (this can be e.g. done in Cura or Pronterface). I used the terminal available in the OctoPrint interface.
Send the code: M206 X-2 Y2. The values specified are added to the endstop position when the axes are referenced, so this tells the printer that the center of the printer is located at the given values with respect to the stored values in the configuration file. To store the new center send code M500.

The first photo shows the before center calibration, the second photo after calibration.

Now your printer has a new center!

comments.text: Very Helpful,

With all that said, it is perfectly legit to make a .gcode file yourself and run that file using the SD card.

NEW AND IMPROVED!
Revision 4 has modified outlets which direct air flow in a more downward direction, and less toward the nozzles. Also, STEP & IGES file formats (R4) are now posted. Made to fit a third 40mm fan for active cooling. The reason I designed this is because I wanted to get air all around the print. Having air coming from just the front was not working well for my needs. Check out some great before and after pictures here: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:75635 This design hugs a little closer to the extruder carriage than some other versions. This keeps it away from the front door hinge bolts! Helpful for PLA and ABS prints. Find the NEW Flash Forge version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:259688

This thing is designed to print at 0.2 layer height, 2 shells, and 15% fill, no raft or support. I had a little trouble with bridging over the ducts. My solution was to turn off bridging and change the solid layer angle to 90 degrees.   
Be sure to clean out any "spaghetti" in the air ways.  
The chrome fan guards need to be removed. The fan bolts are M3-10.

comments.text: are you all using this duct to print PLA on the R2X or using it to print ABS?
comments.author: Apru

comments.text:
Good Question. The answer is, both.
From my experience, PLA seems
to benefit from the cooling duct operating continuously from the start,
no matter what the model looks like. Also keeping the door and top of the REP2X open.
Whereas
with ABS, I only turn on this duct for models that need it. And, NEVER
at the very beginning of a print, where the ABS needs to stay hot to
stick to the build plate.
Models with overhangs or thin parts show the most benefit of additional cooling.
ABS prints of models that are "blocky" forms do best WITHOUT THIS DUCT AT ALL (while keeping the REP2X tightly closed up). In fact, they may warp and separate from the build plate if cooled too much.
With experience and testing, most users can do a good job of predicting when this duct will be needed, or not.

title: Wave ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A wave ring created with VECTARY.https://www.vectary.com/l/Wave_ring

How we made it:

  1. Create a tube with 8 segments.
  2. Select the opposite edges and move them up to make a sort of a wave silhouette.
  3. Bevel the edges.
  4. Use radial array, make 3 copies and then rotate it.
  5. Turn on the modifier, select the last object and then move it up.
  6. Bake array and smooth object.
  7. Choose the color and material you want to be applied.
  8. Export the .stl file.

I made this as a fix to my son's RC monster truck that seems to be very prone to breaking at the wheel hub where the drive shaft connects to the wheels. To make the part work, it was printed at a resolution of 0.1mm (although lower resolution would still work) with an infill of 80% on a Makerbot 5th Gen in PLA, although I would of preferred ABS or tough PLA. Be sure to lay it flat to ensure the layers of plastic run horizontally for strength. Once printed, the metal shaft was inserted after drilling out the hole to fit and adhered with Crazy Glue. I hope this can help others who might have this $100 toy, as it is otherwise a well-made product aside from this one design flaw. This is why Thingiverse is such a great thing!

title: Stone ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A low poly ring created with VECTARY https://www.vectary.com/l/Stone_ring

1. Make a tube
  2. Bevel the edges.
  3. Draw a box and bevel the edges.
  4. Use the box with radial array.
  5. Set the angle to 120 degrees and +/- 30 copies.
  6. Play with the jitter settings in Array to make it look more random.
  7. Bake array.
  8. Use Boolean to join the tube and array together and then bake.
  9. Smooth and choose the color and material you want to be applied.
  10. Export the .stl file.
